bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Emilie Lawrence Reed, [April 1924]

div1.p: Kean informs Emilie Lawrence Reed that Hendrick will print a correction to an earlier article. This letter is written at the bottom of Hendrick's letter to Kean, dated April 16, 1924. Hendrick writes that the corrections will be made and regrets any offense given Emilie Lawrence Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Emilie Lawrence Reed, [April 1924]
div1.p:
THE WORLD'S WORK
Garden City New York
April 16, 1924. My dear Colonel Kean,

I shall be glad to publish in the WORLD'S WORK the
correction contained in your letter. It will appear in an
early number. I regret very much that the necessity of con-
densing this chapter produced a result which has given pain
to Mrs. Reed. In the original version Dr. Reed's work is
described in detail and particular emphasis laid upon the
fact that Gorgas' chief claim to fame is that he put into
operation so successfully the Reed discovery. Another man
who suffers rather severely is Dr. Carter whose work is also
described in detail but of whom practically no mention is
made in the magazine article. Such lapses as this are in-
evitable in magazine publication.
With many thanks for the tone of your note,

Sincerely yours,
(Signed) Burton J. Hendrick
Col. J. R. Kean,
Headquarters First Corps Area,
Army Base,
Boston 9, Mass.

Easter Greetings and all good
wishes to you- I wish a pretty pusy
was going with it- Here is a letter
(copy) from Mr Hendrick which is
much more satisfactory- When he
prints my criticism in can consider the
incident as closed I think- With all good wishes
